titlestmt.titleproper: McTyeire, Holland Nimmons and William and Janie Baskervill Papers – faculty
Finding Aid for the Mctyeire-Baskervill Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

repository.corpname: Special Collections Manuscripts and Rare Books

did.unittitle: Mctyeire-Baskervill Papers

Correspondence: 333 items, including 113 holograph letters, 45 typed originals, 70 carbon or typed copies, 1 manuscript copy, 1 holograph note, 1 post card, and 2 telegrams. The correspondence is largely comprised of the incoming letters of Holland Nimmons McTyeire, Jamie McTyeire Baskervill, and William Malone Baskervill. 73 items sire addressed to H.N.M., 82 to J.M.B., emd 72 to W.M.B. Also included is a folder of correspondence to and from Devereux Lake, concerning the ’’Golden Link” (their wives) between Bishop McTyeire and Commodore Vanderbilt.
Manuscripts smd personal papers of Holland Nimmons McTyeire, Janie McTyeire Baskervill? and William Malone Baskervill.
Papers of Holland Nimmons McTyeire:

4 newsletters addressed to and apparently published in the Southern Christian Advocate, dated 6 March 1862, 12 February 1863, 26 March 1Ö63, and 11 June 1863. The first, headed ’’Reliable News from Nashville,” is signed ”H. N. McTyeire." The other three, headed "Letter from the Country,” are signed "M.P.,” and may be by someone else. (1-4)
5 items relating to publication of H.N. McTyeire's book History of Methodism by Southern Methodist Publishing House. TB)
2 lists of licenses and certificates in H.N.M's hand, and Mobile, Alabama, licence to perform weddings, dated 3 February 1848. (6)
3 holograph wills (each with typewritten copy) of H.N.M., dated 28 June 188I, 25 August 1884, and 29 July 1885. (6-7)

Vanderbilt University papers: manuscript identure between V.U. and Ward Seminary, dated 30 June 1888 (6 pages); List of Exchanges drawn upon W.H. Vanderbilt, New York, by Bishop H.N. McTyeire, n.d. (2 pages, manuscript); typed copy of V.U. (i.e. Central University) Board of Trust resolution accepting gift of C. Vanderbilt, 26 March 1873J 2 typed copies, signed by secretary, of Board of Trust reorganization report, 20 June 1888; White River Annual Conference of Methodist Episcopal Church South, December 1888, approval of action of V.U. Board (1 page, manuscript); V.U. Board resolution in appreciation of H.N. McTyeire, after his death, 15 February 1889 (2 pages, manuscript); 5 resolutions, written in pencil on slips of paper, mostly dating from after MjtTyeire's death (n.d.). (8-9) McTyeire family history: 3 pages from McTyeire family Bible, recording births, marriages, and deaths, 17951871 (copied 1886); 4 manuscript pages recording Nimmons and McTyeire family births, marriages, and deaths, 17901876; 5-page carbon copy of "Notes on My Visit to Barnwell « . ." by John J. Tigert IV, 23 May 1935; 2-page carbon copy of "Inscriptions on the graves in the family cemetery of the McTyeires at Uchee . . ." (n.d.); 1 ms. page Everitt-Vanderbilt family history; 1 typescript page Crawford family history; 1 ms. page Townsend family history; 1 ms. page Nimmons family history. (11-12)
"Holland Nimmons McTyeire," 8-page typescript address delivered by Rev. John J. Lafferty, 24 February 1889, with notes in pencil and ink by E.B.W. (Elizabeth Basker- vill Wall). (13)
Manuscripts of Janie McTyeire Baskervill:

Family and V.U.-related manuscripts: notes for life of Holland N. McTyeire (10 assorted ms. pages); "Mrs. Frank A. Vanderbilt" (24K ms. pages); "Amelia McTyeire Tigert. In Memoriam" (9 ms. pages); "Our Sister, Mary Gayle McTyeire Hamilton" (9 assorted ms. pages); frag, on life of William Malone Baskervill (1 ms. page); notes on life of John McTyeire (father of H.N. McTyeire) (2 ms. pages); frag, draft of letter on McTyeire-Vanderbilt connection and founding of University (2 ms. pages); 3 lines of verse ofi books (quote); "Inspiration of Difficulty" (2 ms. pages); "Kate Marian McTyeire" (7 ms. pages); "Founding and early history of Vanderbilt Women's Club" (draft of letter, 5 ms. pages). (14-20)
Literary manuscripts—papers read by J.M.B. before Vanderbilt Women's Club: "The Women of Shakespeare" (41 ms. pages), "Hamlet" (42 ms. pages), "Scottish Poetry" (48 ms. pages). (21-33)'
Manuscripts and papers of William Mellone Baskervill:

"Southern Literature" (address)(52 ms. pages); "Maurice Thompson" (address)(49 ms. pages);"Select Poems of Sidney Latileh" (book review)(7 ms. pages); "American Literature" (bibliography)and notes)(11 pages, ms., in notebook); "The Victorian Age" (39 ms. pages in notebook); "The Romantic Poets" (9 ms. pages); "James Russell Lowell" (2 ms. pages); fragment on Georgian English literature (15 ms. pages). (34-48)

Diplomas and certificates from Randolph Macon College (5 items), universities of Leipzig and Heidelberg (7 items); other German items (4 items); Wofford College resolutions (2 items); article on W.M.B. (2-page typed carbon). (49-52)
Manuscripts by unknown authors: "Charles Samuel Griffith" (11 pages) and notes on Frank A. Vanderbilt (1 page). (53)

Photographs: Richard Malcolm Johnston, Samuel Mintum Peck (3), Thomas Nelson Page, 1 unidentified (Amelia McTyeire? Martha Crawford?); postcard of Sidney Lanier’s birthplace; 5 small snapshots of Collingsworth Institution. (1)
Holland N. McTyeire's memorandum book for 1866. (2)
Clippings and other printed items:

note.p: Articles by Holland N. McTyeire: "Burying a Father," "My Old Servant, 'Uncle Cy.'" (3)

Articles about Holland N. McTyeire: "Bishop H.N. McTyeire. The Funeral Services," "Undertones of Bishop McTyeire," "MyTyeire Memorial Service," "The Vanderbilt Celebration," "Memorial Address—The Founders and Organizers of Vanderbilt University," "Bishop Holland N. McTyeire." (4) (see also folder 10)
Articles mentioning Holland N. McTyeire. (5-7)
Southern Christian Advocate, Aug. 21, Sept. 4, Oct. 2, Oct 16, 18Ó2. (8-9)
Articles by Janie McTyeire Baskervill: "Bishop Holland N. McTyeire," "Wailter Montgomery McTyeire," "Margaret J. Preston," "Edward Emerson Barnard," "The Twelve World Pictures," parts 1 and 2. (10)

Articles by William Malone Baskervill: "The Anglo-Saxon Version of the 'Epistola Alexandri ad Aristoielem" (dissertation, Leipzig), "Atticus Greene Haygood," "Jaimes Russell Lowell," "Welcome Address." (11-12)

Articles about William Malone Baskervill: "William Malone Baskervill" (obituary), "William Malone Baskervill and His Pupils," "The Personal Side of Dr. Baskervill," "Doctor William Malone Baskervill," "Many Writers Acknowledge Literary Debt to Baskervill." (13) (see also folder for obituary by Charles Forster Smith)
W.M. Baskervill's "Southern Writer" series — notices and reviews. (14)
McTyeire family — obituaries: Amelia Townsend McTyeire, Kate Marianye McTyeire, Amelia McTyeire Tigert, Mary McTyeire Hamilton, Walter M. McTyeire. (15)
Townsend and Baskervill families — obituaries and articles: Jane Townsend, Dr. John T. Baskervill, Charles Read Baskervill. (16)
Vanderbilt family: "In Memoria» — Cornelius Vanderbilt," etc. (17)
Edward Emerson Barnard — articles not by J.M. Baskervill. (19)
Southern writers — articles not by W.M. Baskervill: articles on James Lane Allen, George W. Cable, Joel Chandler Harris, Thomas Nelson Page, Irwin Russell, Sidney Lanier, Maurice Thompson. (20-23)
Candler-Kelley controversy (1887). (24-25)
Vanderbilt University. (26-30)
Nashville. (31-32)
World War I — maps, etc. (33)
Miscellaneous. (34)

did.unittitle: A series of lists made in October 1943 by Elizabeth Baskervill Wall, daughter of William Malone and Janie McTyeire Baskervill.

note.p: The lists are of manuscripts, letters and clippings saved by her mother, and include all the items in the present McTyeire- Baskervill. The lists accompanied the material which she sent to Vanderbilt University in 1943» but some items are listed which she did not send, sind other items have apparently been separated from the collection or misplaced since the collection has been in the Joint University Libraries.
The lists are usefill, since the material is arranged by subject and the compiler comments on the significance of vsirious items, and quotes extensively from others as an aid to identification.
The lists are as follows:

blockquote.p: Papers relating to Bishop McTyeire, Commodore Vanderbilt etc. (l6 pages, typed)
Papers relating to William Malone Baskervill (15 pages, typed)
Telegrams to Bishop Holland N. McTyeire (3 pages, typed)
Clippings and letters pertaining to early history of Vanderbilt University and Barnardiana (5 pages, typed).

note.p: Envelopes removed from correspondence in box 1. Envelopes which are in themselves informative, i.e., with name of writer if not given on letter or with manuscript notes concerning letter, have been kept with the letters.
Elizabeth Baskervill’Wall's pencilled labels for envelopes in which she sent material. Since material has been rearranged, her categories are no longer pertinent, but her labels may be of interest.

index.head: (Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by writer. Number of letters by each writer is given, in parentheses, after name of writer and before date of letter and name of addressee. Addressees H.N.M., J.M.B., and W.M.B. are, respectively, Holland Nimmons McTyeire, Janie McTyeire Baskervill, and William Malone Baskervill. All correspondence is in box 1.)

userestrict.head: From The Sullins Reflector, Vol. 6, No. 3 (Nov. 23. 1942):
userestrict.p: Mrs. Janie Baskervill, "Our Friend," Former Dean of Girls Dies at Sullins, November 5
Gave Generously of Her Talent; Interested in Community Affairs

"Mrs. Janie McTyeire Baskervill, one of the most widely known and most dearly loved women in educational circles of the south, died in her apartment at Sullins College, Thursday, November 5, at 5:30 a.m., after an illness of eight weeks. Funeral services, in charge of Dr. J. Stewart French, assisted by Dr. J.E. Hicks and Dr. H.H. Thompson, were held at the home of Dr. and Mrs. W.E. Martin on Glènway avenue, Friday, November 6, at 10:30 a.m. Burial was made in Mount Olivet cemetery, Nashville, Tennessee.

"Mrs. Baskervill, daughter of the late Bishop Holland Nimmons McTyeire and Amelia Townsend McTyeire, was born April 8, 1862, in Mobile, Alabama. During her early childhood she moved to Nashville, Tennessee, where her father was president of the Vanderbilt University board and senior bishop of the Methodist Church. It was he, Bishop Holland Nimmons McTyeire, who prevailed upon General Cornelius Vanderbilt, noted New York philanthropist, to establish the university.
"Her husband, the late Dr. William Malone Baskervill who died in 1899, was head of the department of English University and was one of the founders of the Southern Association of Colleges.

"Since coming to Bristol as dean of women at old Sullins College, she had been active in community affairs for many years. With her daughter, Mrs« William E. Martin, and Dr. Martin, Mrs. Baskervill moved to Woman's College in Montgomery, Alabama, and served there as dean of women. For a great many years she held the position as dean of girls and social director at Sullins College.

"Mrs. Baskervill showed deep interest in women's clubs of Bristol and offered much to their organization. She was a member of the Woman's History Club, Gibbon History Club, and the Ann Carter Lee Chapter of the U.D.C. .
"Mrs. Baskervill has had charge of promoting the annual Red Cross Drive at Sullins College for the past several years, and has always been very enthusiastic and highly successful with this project.

"Surviving are two daughters, Mrs. William E. Martin of Bristol and Mrs. Elizabeth Baskervill Wall of Bedford, Virginia; one son, William Malone Baskervill of Baltimore; one step-son, John Adams Baskervill of Nashville; seven grandchildren, Mrs. Garland Osborne and Mrs. Raymond Bailey of Bristol, Mrs. Francis Cash of Cincinnati, Ohio, William Thomas Martin of New York, N.Y., Misses Dorothy, Evelyn, and Jane Baskervill of Baltimore, Maryland; and five great-grandchildren."

userestrict.head: From Alumnus Magazine« Vol. XXVIII, No. 2 (November, 1942), p. 2:
userestrict.p: ‘Mrs. Janie McTyeire Baskervill, one of the most widely known women in Southern educational circles, died on November 5» at Sullins College, Bristol, Virginia, after an illness of eight weeks. She was buried at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Nashville.

"Mrs. Baskervill, who was dean of Sullins College for many'years, came to Nashville from Mobile, Ala., in her early childhood. She was the daughter of the late Bishop Holland Nimmons McTyeire, for many years President of the Vanderbilt University Board of Trust and Senior Bishop of The Methodist Church. Her husband, the late Dr. William Monroe /i.e. Malone/Baskervill, who died in 1899» was head of the Department of English at Vanderbilt University and was one of the founders of the Southern Association of Colleges.

"Going to Bristol as dean of women at old Sullins College, Mrs. Baskervill had been active in community affairs of the city for many years. With her daughter, Mrs. William E. Martin, and Dr. Martin, Mrs. Baskervill moved to Woman's College in Montgomery, Ala., and served there as dean of women. For years she held the position as "dean of girls" at the present Sullins College »

"Mrs. Baskervill is survived by two daughters, Mrs. William E. Martin, A'02, of Bristol and Mrs. Elizabeth Wall, Ax'07, of Bedford, Va.; one son, William Malone Baskervill, Ax'10, of Baltimore; one stepson, John Adams Baskervill, Lx'06, of Nashville; seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren."
